metadata.synopsis: Astarion's Topical greetings - once-off introductions to his default InParty dialog that play depending on the location/recent events in the game.

4.speaker: Astarion
4.text: Ha! Defeating a devil in his own home feels very, very good, actually.

5.speaker: Astarion
5.text: The sooner we get out of this gith warren, the better.

214.speaker: Astarion
214.text: We don't all blend in as well as you do. Although I imagine that'll change if we ever reach Baldur's Gate.

10.speaker: Astarion
10.text: I have to admit, I am impressed with Gale and his new lantern.

426.speaker: Astarion
426.text: Being willing to turn away from what he knew and bending the darkness to his will? Wonderful to see.

177.speaker: Astarion
177.text: And of course the dead pixies were just a lovely touch.

17.speaker: Astarion
17.text: I don't envy the choice that mind flayer gave you, but for what it's worth, I think you did the right thing.

20.speaker: Astarion
20.text: You gave up your freedom to save your father? I will never understand you, Ravengard.

21.speaker: Astarion
21.text: So, are we saving this 'Nere' from suffocating or leaving him to die?

383.speaker: Astarion
383.text: I'm fine with either, naturally. The last thing I want is to ruin these nails digging through rock.

235.speaker: Player
235.text: Of course - we can't leave him to die!

519.speaker: Astarion
519.context: NodeContext: "That's hilarious", but cut off. Astarion genuinely thinks the player was joking with "we can't leave him to die"

117.speaker: Astarion
117.text: Well of course we can leave him, it's the easiest thing in the world. We just have to keep on walking.

256.speaker: Astarion
256.text: But if you insist on being a hero, I won't get in your way. Just don't expect me to help either.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: We probably should, if only for the gnomes' sakes...

459.speaker: Astarion
459.text: Gods, really? Saving a drow I can understand, but saving gnomes?
459.context: NodeContext: Doesn't think much of gnomes

28.speaker: Player
28.text: We're busy, we can't stop for everyone we meet.

234.speaker: Astarion
234.text: I could not agree more. To hells with them all.

24.speaker: Astarion
24.text: Just when you think your day can't get any stranger, you end up traipsing around an impossible-looking shadow dimension.

247.speaker: Astarion
247.text: Honestly, just once could we end up somewhere normal?

180.speaker: Astarion
180.text: A tavern maybe? Or a nice, friendly brothel? I'd take anything at this rate.

25.speaker: Astarion
25.text: I've been in more unsettling places than this, but not many.

26.speaker: Astarion
26.text: Defying Mystra, declaring that he'll rule the Karsite Weave - I didn't know Gale had it in him.

30.speaker: Astarion
30.text: At last. Time to enjoy a little vengeance.

32.speaker: Astarion
32.text: I don't see what Shadowheart got so upset about - it was not that nice of a temple.

39.speaker: Astarion
39.text: Should I be surprised that the key to freeing this gith prince is a hammer?

183.speaker: Astarion
183.text: It's as subtle and elegant as everything the gith do.

43.speaker: Astarion
43.text: We have a new look for a new Shadowheart.

11.speaker: Astarion
11.text: Nice as it is, she still doesn't have the best hair in the camp.
11.context: NodeContext: Astarion is praising his own hair here.

44.speaker: Astarion
44.text: Jaheira has steel in her, I'll say that. It's not easy to walk away from immortality.

449.speaker: Astarion
449.text: Most people would have held on to that scroll for as long as they could bear to. And probably a century or two longer than that.

50.speaker: Astarion
50.text: I had another visit from that dream figure. I take it you did too? It claims that if we infiltrate the heart of the cult that's giving out these parasites, we'll find the answers we're looking for.

76.speaker: Astarion
76.text: It gave me another gift, too. Just like it did the first time it appeared. Rather generous, if you ask me.

270.speaker: Player
270.text: Seems straightforward to me. If we want to infiltrate Moonrise Towers, these tadpole gifts might be the best way to do it.

236.speaker: Astarion
236.text: And while we're at it, we can see how many more of these little worms we can harvest.

221.speaker: Player
221.text: To infiltrate the cult, we must be discreet - the tadpole can help us with that.

162.speaker: Astarion
162.text: And if that fails, then there's always killing them quietly.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: Whatever's at the heart of this cult, we have to find it, by any means possible.

412.speaker: Player
412.text: I don't like it. This whole thing feels like a trap.

167.speaker: Astarion
167.text: On the one hand, you're right. On the other, don't be so wet behind the ears.

61.speaker: Astarion
61.text: So, we can add one bald wall of muscle to our little group.

189.speaker: Astarion
189.text: I'm sure he'll come in handy. Maybe as a doorstop.

62.speaker: Astarion
62.text: I can't believe Mystra's demanding Gale sacrifice himself to destroy the Absolute.
62.context: InternalNodeContext: Gale Avatar is NOT speaker, we know about his bomb

508.speaker: Astarion
508.text: It's just a waste of a perfectly good cult that we could be controlling.

441.speaker: Astarion
441.text: And a waste of a perfectly good Gale, I suppose.

75.speaker: Astarion
75.text: Ah, drink it in - that sweet, sweet chaos.

475.speaker: Astarion
475.text: Not that I approve of goblins, of course - filthy little beasts - but I do like a good den of debauchery.

79.speaker: Astarion
79.text: This place is miserable, even for the house of a god.

88.speaker: Astarion
88.text: I really thought you and the gith might fight to the death over that artefact.

226.speaker: Astarion
226.text: A pity, it would have made for a fine night's entertainment.

94.speaker: Astarion
94.text: Careful not to inhale too much smoke, your lungs won't appreciate it.

268.speaker: Astarion
268.text: Not a worry for those of us who don't breathe, of course.

381.speaker: Astarion
381.text: Although maybe you're used to it? I imagine this feels just like home.

96.speaker: Astarion
96.text: There's one more stone in our pockets, which means one step closer to glory.

503.speaker: Astarion
503.text: Or however this sordid tale ends. I wouldn't want to presume.

99.speaker: Astarion
99.text: Well, this is exciting. It's not every day you get to speak to a god-queen.

220.speaker: Astarion
220.text: Much less be bossed around by one.

104.speaker: Astarion
104.text: I thought I knew what it was like to be a prisoner, but this place is something else entirely.

109.speaker: Astarion
109.text: Your parents are at peace. And so're you, it seems.

112.speaker: Astarion
112.text: Good riddance to the shapechanger. Couldn't have happened to a worse wretch.

114.speaker: Astarion
114.text: It was sickening, watching Lae'zel bow to that monstrosity. I thought she was stronger.
114.context: NodeContext: Disappointed - he's watching Lae'zel bow to her version of Cazador

6.speaker: Astarion
6.text: Some just grow to love their chains, I suppose.
6.context: NodeContext: Disappointed - he's watching Lae'zel bow to her version of Cazador

428.speaker: Astarion
428.text: Some of us reach for freedom, while others just grow to love their chains, I suppose.
428.context: NodeContext: Disappointed - he's watching Lae'zel bow to her version of Cazador

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Do not preach to me - you do not know my life.

437.speaker: Astarion
437.text: I know enough of it. I've lived enough of it. But if you won't hear me, that's on you.

488.speaker: Astarion
488.text: So, if you don't want to discuss the truth, what do you want from me?

254.speaker: Player
254.text: How dare you speak against my queen!

362.speaker: Astarion
362.text: Fine. If you don't want to hear the truth, I can't force your ears open.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: And I thought you were smarter. Keep your mouth shut in future.

257.speaker: Astarion
257.text: Oh, certainly. If you want to live in ignorance, I'm happy to let you die in it too.

115.speaker: Astarion
115.text: This place brings back the worst memories. It's like being kidnapped all over again.

119.speaker: Astarion
119.text: So, Lae'zel's going to war with Vlaakith? Going to break her chains in Baldur's Gate?

123.speaker: Astarion
123.text: I am enjoying the latest addition to our little group - Lae'zel is delightful.

248.speaker: Astarion
248.text: In a very 'look at me twice and I'll dismember you' kind of way, of course.

127.speaker: Astarion
127.text: So, we kill Gortash or Gale dies? It's not an easy call.

510.speaker: Astarion
510.text: One the one hand, killing Gortash would be fun. On the other, Gale can be very annoying.

499.speaker: Astarion
499.text: We probably should save the wizard, though. He does have his moments.

128.speaker: Astarion
128.text: So, it was you who got us into this mess? All along, we were travelling with the creator of the Absolute...

416.speaker: Astarion
416.text: I won't lie, I'm a little impressed.

309.speaker: Astarion
309.text: If it wasn't for you, I'd still be stuck in Cazador's kennels. So, thank you. For being that evil bastard.

129.speaker: Astarion
129.text: So one of our own was the leader of an entire cult?

130.speaker: Astarion
130.text: So, the untouchable Karlach is untouchable no more.

190.speaker: Astarion
190.text: I'd shake her hand, but she can still snap me in two, so... probably safest to skip it.

135.speaker: Astarion
135.text: So, we have a shapechanger at our camp? Good luck finding her.

457.speaker: Astarion
457.text: You could watch out for anyone acting strangely, but... well, you know the lunatics we camp with.

136.speaker: Astarion
136.text: There's a time for talking and a time for killing. This, my friend, is the latter.

140.speaker: Astarion
140.text: Killing that giant oaf was the right thing to do. Even if it meant losing the Harper.

143.speaker: Astarion
143.text: I'm not surprised that the gith's insane device didn't remove our tadpoles. I'm just disappointed.

144.speaker: Astarion
144.text: It's not enough we have a gallery of villains to look out for, but now we could be infiltrated by a shapechanger?

494.speaker: Astarion
494.text: I can't even tell if any of you are acting strange because you've been replaced or because this group is full of weirdos.

147.speaker: Astarion
147.text: Nightsong will be pleased to know Lorroakan isn't after her hide anymore.

107.speaker: Astarion
107.text: Although she may be even more pleased to know who put that bounty on her head in the first place.

151.speaker: Astarion
151.text: So, Gale's hedging his bets with Mystra. I can't say I blame him.

155.speaker: Astarion
155.text: It feels like we're being watched - hunted, even - but there's nothing out there, only more darkness.

364.speaker: Astarion
364.text: I much prefer it when I'm the one prowling in the shadows, about to strike.

325.speaker: Astarion
325.text: Sorry - did you want something? Or just looking for a distraction?

157.speaker: Astarion
157.text: Wyrm's Crossing - the 'Welcome' mat of Baldur's Gate.

56.speaker: Astarion
56.text: This is it. I'm almost home.
56.context: NodeContext: Mixed feelings, both nostalgic for home, but also scared of what's waiting for him

161.speaker: Astarion
161.text: I wasn't sure you'd want to talk, after Gortash and... well, everything.

509.speaker: Astarion
509.text: I wish I could tell you dying isn't so bad, but my experience has been quite... specific. Sorry.
509.context: NodeContext: trying to cheer her up, realises he's failing badly

520.speaker: Player
520.text: It's all right. I'm all right.

152.speaker: Astarion
152.text: You don't have to be. Sometimes things are just terrible.

84.speaker: Astarion
84.text: But if you say you're all right, I believe you.

528.speaker: Astarion
528.text: So, what shall we talk about?

280.speaker: Player
280.text: Yeah. This just kind of sucks, you know?

480.speaker: Astarion
480.text: I was trying to think of something more profound to say, but no. It just 'kind of sucks.'

93.speaker: Astarion
93.text: That being said, moping changes nothing. So, what's next?

34.speaker: Player
34.text: Don't mention it. Like... literally, let's not talk about it.

163.speaker: Astarion
163.text: Well, Grand Duke Ravengard. A position like that comes with a lot of wealth and luxury.

450.speaker: Astarion
450.text: If you survive long enough to enjoy it.

164.speaker: Astarion
164.text: I suppose it was only a matter of time until Shar took vengeance.

327.speaker: Astarion
327.text: For the Lady of Loss, she does not like losing.

165.speaker: Astarion
165.text: So, Mystra's requested a chat with you? Unusually polite for a god.

47.speaker: Astarion
47.text: I do hope it goes well. We've pissed off enough gods already.

166.speaker: Astarion
166.text: Nothing like a little camp drama to spice up the evening.

303.speaker: Astarion
303.text: It's almost a pity things ended so amicably, seeing those two duke it out would be fun.

168.speaker: Astarion
168.text: So, it's a quest to free Shadowheart's parents, is it?

74.speaker: Astarion
74.text: And here I was worried I'd be the only one with a difficult family reunion waiting in the city.

171.speaker: Astarion
171.text: Well, this seems like a lovely little spot. The sense of impending doom aside.

36.speaker: Astarion
36.text: Well, it's a 'run down, bearing the weight of centuries' sort of grand. Which is my favourite kind, incidentally.

186.speaker: Astarion
186.text: I think I'll enjoy travelling with Halsin.

360.speaker: Astarion
360.text: Not for his wit or wisdom - he'll just make an excellent shield if we're attacked.

525.speaker: Astarion
525.text: To think, he's had that orb within him this whole time and never told us.

73.speaker: Astarion
73.text: Who'd keep a secret like that from his friends? You can't trust anyone these days.

193.speaker: Astarion
193.text: I knew we were a strange band, but a fugitive from the Hells? Now that's someone worth knowing.

145.speaker: Astarion
145.text: Not that I want to get on the wrong side of any devils, but this Karlach is a survivor.

261.speaker: Astarion
261.text: Plus, I appreciate anyone who opens a conversation with threats of bodily harm.

194.speaker: Astarion
194.text: It's quite a trick, coming back from the dead. If only we were all so lucky.

197.speaker: Astarion
197.text: That drider's mad as a box of gremishkas.

483.speaker: Astarion
483.text: Then again, you'd have to be mad to spend your days marching through this gloom.

198.speaker: Astarion
198.text: Well, no tentacles yet. I suppose we can consider that a success.

201.speaker: Astarion
201.text: Minsc puts on quite a show of brawn. Even if there's no brain worth mentioning.

274.speaker: Astarion
274.text: I mean, I hate to judge the proverbial book, but that oaf may be all cover and no pages.

202.speaker: Astarion
202.text: So, we've picked up a wizard who managed to get stuck in his own portal? Hardly a promising introduction.

206.speaker: Astarion
206.text: What a waste - Gale could have had a taste of real power.

304.speaker: Astarion
304.text: Instead he bowed to the will of his god and traded it for a sad little boon. Pathetic.

207.speaker: Astarion
207.text: So, we owe our lack of tentacles to one of the very creatures that kidnapped us.

367.speaker: Astarion
367.text: At least my lack of tentacles. I'm not sure what's next for you.
367.context: NodeContext: Player's turned partially into a mind flayer

518.speaker: Astarion
518.text: At least you showed it what you thought of its offer. Nicely done.
518.context: NodeContext: Player stamped on tadpole the mind flayer offered them, killing it

354.speaker: Astarion
354.text: And now it's offering us power. If we're willing to 'evolve'.

213.speaker: Astarion
213.text: Poor Wyll gave you the benefit of the doubt and it earned him a set of horns.
213.context: NodeContext: Speaking to Karlach, discussing Wyll after he's been turned into a devil and given a set of horns because he took mercy on her.

368.speaker: Astarion
368.text: Not that they don't look flattering on him. Almost everything does.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: I didn't know - I never would have asked him to do that.

502.speaker: Astarion
502.text: Of course not, darling! You mustn't blame yourself.

348.speaker: Astarion
348.text: And maybe this will help him relate to you a little better. You're both sporting horns now, after all.

411.speaker: Player
411.text: He made his choice. That's not on me.

491.speaker: Player
491.text: They do look pretty good, don't they?

217.speaker: Astarion
217.text: So, we're travelling with the famed 'Blade of Frontiers'. I feel safer already.
217.context: NodeContext: He does not, in fact, feel safer

218.speaker: Astarion
218.text: Obviously I'm glad we didn't level the monastery with that sun cannon. But...

363.speaker: Astarion
363.text: Come on, you can't say you weren't a little curious to see what would happen?
363.context: NodeContext: playfully, as if trying to worm a guilty secret out of you

271.speaker: Astarion
271.text: Really? Where's your sense of curiosity?

476.speaker: Astarion
476.text: Some people just don't appreciate the wonders the world has to hold, I suppose.

342.speaker: Player
342.text: Do not jest about slaying my kin, elf.

419.speaker: Astarion
419.text: Gods, lighten up. Enjoy a joke, it won't kill you.

98.speaker: Astarion
98.text: Or... maybe it will? I honestly have no idea with you people.

371.speaker: Player
371.text: Do not jest about slaying my kin, vampire.

485.speaker: Player
485.text: We're not all as messed up as you.

493.speaker: Astarion
493.text: I knew it! There's no shame in being curious about power. It is exhilarating.

477.speaker: Astarion
477.text: And who knows? Maybe we'll have better luck with our next weapon of incomprehensible destruction.

222.speaker: Astarion
222.text: Now there's a bloody devil trailing after us? This gets better and better.

397.speaker: Astarion
397.text: 'Shop around', he said. He seems sure we won't find anything.

377.speaker: Astarion
377.text: Given that a hag couldn't solve our wriggling little problem, he might be right.

215.speaker: Player
215.text: Raphael holds no secrets to cleansing. He will suffer for goading us.

372.speaker: Astarion
372.text: I hope you're right, but I don't like this. He's playing with us.
372.context: NodeContext: 'this' = having met a devil that seems to know more about our situation than we do

432.speaker: Astarion
432.text: He reminds me of - well, someone I used to know. Someone that liked to play with people.

326.speaker: Astarion
326.text: Cazador liked to toy with people too. Let them think there was hope right until the end. Until he snatched it all away.

169.speaker: Astarion
169.text: Creatures like them don't play games unless they know they can win.

388.speaker: Player
388.text: We're not his playthings - we'll show him that.

399.speaker: Astarion
399.text: Maybe, but he's not the only one spinning a web for us.

343.speaker: Astarion
343.text: We keep hunting for answers. What other choice do we have?
343.context: NodeContext: response to 'what do you suggest?'

355.speaker: Astarion
355.text: This is no ordinary mind flayer parasite. Who tampered with it and why? What do they have planned for us?

196.speaker: Astarion
196.text: And why are we important enough that a devil comes knocking on our door? If we find those answers, we might have a chance.
196.context: NodeContext: a devil knocking on your door seems very suspicious

521.speaker: Player
521.text: You might not be able to outfox him, but I will.

393.speaker: Astarion
393.text: Oh, will you? Because you've got it all figured out, I'm sure.

282.speaker: Astarion
282.text: You know who tampered with the parasite. And why. And what they have planned for us.
282.context: NodeContext: Annoyed that the player is assuming they have answers when they don't

102.speaker: Astarion
102.text: And of course you know why we're interesting enough that a devil would come to proposition us. Because if you don't know that, you may as well sign over your soul now.

238.speaker: Astarion
238.text: We may escape whatever web we're trapped in, but until we know what's going on, this Raphael has us exactly where he wants us.

472.speaker: Astarion
472.text: Cazador, my old master, liked to toy with people too. Let them think there was hope right until the end. Until he snatched it all away.

33.speaker: Astarion
33.text: You're a warlock. You understand how dangerous the wrong deal can be.

199.speaker: Player
199.text: I know enough to be careful where Raphael's concerned.

139.speaker: Astarion
139.text: I'm glad to hear it, although just being careful might not be enough.

410.speaker: Astarion
410.text: We have to figure out what's happening. Why we aren't changing, what's planned for us, and why a devil is suddenly taking an interest.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: I do. We can't fall into whatever trap Raphael is planning.

95.speaker: Astarion
95.text: Indeed we can't. We have to figure out what's happening. Why we aren't changing, what's planned for us, and why a devil is suddenly taking an interest.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: We're already in danger - trapped between a devil and the mind flayers.

81.speaker: Astarion
81.text: You're not wrong. We have to figure out what's going on. Why we aren't changing, what's planned for us, and why a devil is suddenly taking an interest.

413.speaker: Astarion
413.text: If we can answer those questions, we might have a chance. And if not - well, we'll be exactly where this Raphael wants us.

251.speaker: Player
251.text: Raphael's only a cambion - we can handle him.

443.speaker: Astarion
443.text: Oh, can we? Because you've got it all figured out, I'm sure.

146.speaker: Astarion
146.text: And of course you know why we're interesting enough that a devil - pardon, a cambion - would proposition us. Because if you don't know that, you may as well sign over your soul now.

495.speaker: Astarion
495.text: It reminds me of Cazador, taunting his slaves with hope when he knew the game was rigged.

292.speaker: Astarion
292.text: It reminds me of my old master Cazador, taunting his slaves with hope when he knew the game was rigged.

445.speaker: Player
445.text: We'll have to cross that bridge when we come to it.

175.speaker: Astarion
175.text: If we don't know what we're walking into, that bridge will collapse under us. The devil has a plan - he's playing with us.
175.context: NodeContext: The player's not taking this as seriously as you think they should

361.speaker: Player
361.text: He's not. We still have options.

122.speaker: Astarion
122.text: Maybe, but all that 'take your time, I'll wait' nonsense? He's playing with us.

338.speaker: Player
338.text: If you want to sell your soul, be my guest.

195.speaker: Astarion
195.text: I'm not about to trade a vampiric master for an infernal one. He's playing with us.

300.speaker: Astarion
300.text: I'm not about to throw my soul away. He's playing with us.

403.speaker: Astarion
403.text: And he might be right. We've had no luck so far.

227.speaker: Astarion
227.text: So, Shadowheart chose her family over her god.

260.speaker: Astarion
260.text: I hope she doesn't come to regret it.

228.speaker: Astarion
228.text: If the gith are looking for that artefact, then we may have something valuable on our hands.

471.speaker: Astarion
471.text: And it's a powerful weapon to boot? Things are starting to look very interesting...

231.speaker: Astarion
231.text: To think, Gale's had this devastating orb within himself the entire time, but only just mentioned it?

232.speaker: Astarion
232.text: I thought we were going to see some real sparks fly between Wyll and Karlach.

237.speaker: Astarion
237.text: Useful as the hammer would have been, I'm relieved we're not in the devil's debt.

466.speaker: Astarion
466.text: Once his kind has you under their thumb, they won't ever let you go.

240.speaker: Astarion
240.text: You really don't remember the last while? You don't remember killing anyone?

48.speaker: Player
48.text: No, I don't remember a thing.

358.speaker: Astarion
358.text: All your past, just wiped clean. I don't know if I'm horrified or jealous.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: I remember opening my eyes and standing in Shar's grace. That's all I need.

106.speaker: Astarion
106.text: It seems ignorance truly is bliss. I don't know if I'm horrified or jealous.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: Why? Were they friends of yours?

49.speaker: Astarion
49.text: No, they were your -... never mind. You made your choice.
49.context: NodeContext: Was going to say "no, they were your parents and you killed them", but thought better of it. Shadowheart's had her memory wiped, so she can't remember any of it.

67.speaker: Astarion
67.text: So, what do you need, oh loyal follower of Shar?
67.context: NodeContext: a little bitterly - he doesn't like what Shadowheart's become

242.speaker: Astarion
242.text: So this is the Underdark? I've always heard stories, but never thought I'd end up slumming it down here.

244.speaker: Astarion
244.text: Although it must appeal to anyone with an aversion to the sun, so I suppose it has its upsides.

532.speaker: Astarion
532.text: Or it's... undersides? Because it's - you know what I mean.

245.speaker: Astarion
245.text: So, this is the abode of our dear Absolute? It's about as cheerful as expected.

246.speaker: Astarion
246.text: Good to see Gale's willing to do what it takes to get power. Even if it means defying the gods themselves.

252.speaker: Astarion
252.text: The stink of oil, the clank of gears - this place is revolting.

253.speaker: Astarion
253.text: The Amulet of Bhaal. It's hardly a triumph of fashion, but it does have its uses.

255.speaker: Astarion
255.text: So, Wyll did the right thing and it earned him a set of horns. Let that be a lesson to us all.
255.context: NodeContext: Discussing Wyll after he's been turned into a devil and given a set of horns.

258.speaker: Astarion
258.text: I do admire the décor here. It's more tasty than tasteful, but I'll take what I can get.

263.speaker: Astarion
263.text: I had the strangest dream last night. There was a visitor promising me protection, and all sorts of delicious powers from the parasites in our heads.

395.speaker: Astarion
395.text: Given our shared affliction, I suppose you had a similar dream...?
395.context: NodeContext: fishing for confirmation of something he already believes to be true

209.speaker: Astarion
209.text: Now we can see what these tadpoles can do for us.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: We should take every advantage we can get - let's explore these powers and see where they take us.

134.speaker: Astarion
134.text: Exactly! Waste not, want not - even when it comes to mind flayer parasites.

455.speaker: Player
455.text: I don't trust it. We should avoid using these powers.

284.speaker: Astarion
284.text: Is there a reason you're always such an utter drip? Do you have some sort of condition? Honestly, it's like you hate good news.

430.speaker: Astarion
430.text: Did you actually want something, or are you just here to spoil my fun?

347.speaker: Astarion
347.text: No need to be shy, this is a good thing.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

172.speaker: Astarion
172.text: No need to hide it, this is a good thing.

265.speaker: Astarion
265.text: You know, for all the sense of dread and horror seeping through this place, I really feel quite at home here.

272.speaker: Astarion
272.text: So, the Blade of Frontiers is dead. Long live the Blade of Avernus.

334.speaker: Astarion
334.text: I just hope he stays focused on battling Infernal forces. The undead have it hard enough already.

275.speaker: Astarion
275.text: So, I couldn't help but overhear that your god's commanded you to - well... explode.
275.context: InternalNodeContext: Gale Avatar is speaker, we know about his bomb

526.speaker: Astarion
526.text: You have been dealt a difficult hand, my friend. I'm sorry.

487.speaker: Astarion
487.text: That being said - when you do explode, how far away should I be?
487.context: NodeContext: coming off the back of the previous sincere-sounding line

142.speaker: Player
142.text: I'd rather not explode, quite honestly.

37.speaker: Astarion
37.text: Oh, thank the gods. I was sure you were actually going to do it.

141.speaker: Astarion
141.text: You're... you're not actually going to do it, are you?

341.speaker: Player
341.text: Not if I can help it.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: I cannot say. The power within me is devastating as any Faerûn has ever seen.

425.speaker: Astarion
425.text: I see. So... pretty far, then?

318.speaker: Astarion
318.text: Still, let's hope it doesn't come to that!
318.context: NodeContext: A little nervously - Gale's ability to explode worries him

359.speaker: Astarion
359.text: That's the spirit! Chin up and all that.

64.speaker: Astarion
64.text: Now, was there anything else you wanted?

264.speaker: Player
264.text: You don't understand - it's Mystra's will. I cannot fail her.

396.speaker: Astarion
396.text: You're right, I don't understand. You have a choice, but it sounds like you're actually considering this.

97.speaker: Astarion
97.text: But you need time to think, so I'll leave you be - give you some space.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: Relax, we'll probably die long before that.

3.speaker: Astarion
3.text: Maybe I should just - I'll give you some space.
3.context: NodeContext: Awkwardly trying tp bail on the conversation

233.speaker: Astarion
233.text: As much space as I possibly can.

118.speaker: Player
118.text: Let the silence hang in the air.

224.speaker: Astarion
224.text: Yes, well... I'll leave you to your thoughts. Just - I'll give you space.
224.context: NodeContext: Awkwardly trying to fill the silence until he decides to just bail on the conversation

406.speaker: Player
406.text: What do you mean? You'll be there by my side, won't you?

208.speaker: Astarion
208.text: I'm sorry - me? Oh no, no I don't think so.

470.speaker: Astarion
470.text: I mean, of course I'll support you. I'd just rather do it from a distance. Because of the... explosion.

276.speaker: Astarion
276.text: There's a definite touch of the mythic to this place.

278.speaker: Astarion
278.text: It seems the Blade of Frontiers' legend will only grow from here.

497.speaker: Astarion
497.text: I don't know if Faerûn needed another hero, but Wyll seems happy. I suppose that counts for something.

283.speaker: Astarion
283.text: I never saw myself as a banisher of shadows before.

523.speaker: Astarion
523.text: I was always more of a 'lurker in', historically.

288.speaker: Astarion
288.text: You know, for all the time I've spent lurking in the shadows, I've never ventured into the Underdark before.

400.speaker: Astarion
400.text: Hardly a luxurious setting, but it definitely has its upsides for a vampire.

289.speaker: Astarion
289.text: Gods, that was close. I could almost kiss the boards here, but - well that would be disgusting.

293.speaker: Astarion
293.text: I've known people who were hungry for power, but Gale takes it a bit too literally for my liking.

373.speaker: Astarion
373.text: I wonder how he does it. Why he does it.

126.speaker: Astarion
126.text: I'm sure all will be revealed in time, but I don't like it. A waste of perfectly good treasure.

14.speaker: Astarion
14.text: I know he'll explode if he doesn't, but still. It hurts to see valuable treasure just slurped up.

294.speaker: Astarion
294.text: I'm sorry, but what in the literal Hells was that?
294.context: NodeContext: Just saw Karlach rage and kill some Paladins

346.speaker: Astarion
346.text: Do you often burst into flames or was that a special occasion?

340.speaker: Player
340.text: Both? I don't know. It's complicated.

262.speaker: Astarion
262.text: Still, we all have our little quirks. I'm sure we'll come to appreciate them in time.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: I'll tell you all about it some time. Preferably over a nice cold drink.

287.speaker: Astarion
287.text: That will make for a very interesting evening, I'm sure.

324.speaker: Player
324.text: I don't want to get into it now.

468.speaker: Astarion
468.text: But of course, I wouldn't want to pry.

45.speaker: Astarion
45.text: We all have our little quirks, after all. I'm sure all will be revealed in good time.

295.speaker: Astarion
295.text: I don't relish the idea of Mizora visiting our camp - let alone offering us anything resembling a 'deal'.

463.speaker: Astarion
463.text: When the devils start approaching you, you know you're in deep.

298.speaker: Astarion
298.text: So, this 'Stone Lord' is the legendary Minsc? And a newly-minted cultist, no less.

108.speaker: Astarion
108.text: Are we sure we want to find him before Nine Fingers does? I doubt he'll be pleased to see us.

299.speaker: Astarion
299.text: For what it's worth, I rather like your new look. It adds a sense of drama - a little more flair.
299.context: NodeContext: Speaking to Wyll, after he's been turned into a devil and given a set of horns.

302.speaker: Astarion
302.text: So, Minthara has one in the proverbial oven?

225.speaker: Astarion
225.text: I'm amazed you're still in one piece; I thought she'd bite your head off when she was done with you.

154.speaker: Astarion
154.text: I wonder if she bit the head off her mate after they'd done the deed.

305.speaker: Astarion
305.text: There certainly is a strong ambience down here.

101.speaker: Astarion
101.text: I don't know if it's the bats or the decaying... everything, but it's quite homey.

306.speaker: Astarion
306.text: So, the gith is a killer. Hardly surprising for their people.

317.speaker: Astarion
317.text: Still, it's good to know she's more likely to attack you face on, rather than stabbing you in the back.

307.speaker: Astarion
307.text: So, you persuaded Lae'zel to stay true to Vlaakith? To keep loving her chains.

479.speaker: Astarion
479.text: I hope it was the right call.

308.speaker: Astarion
308.text: I don't like getting caught between the Guild and the Zhentarim. You always make enemies when you take sides in a struggle like that.

524.speaker: Astarion
524.text: And in this case, they're enemies we might not see coming until it's too late.

312.speaker: Astarion
312.text: The parasite must be playing with my ears, because I was sure that beardy tramp told you to find the Heart of the Absolute and then blow yourself up.
312.context: InternalNodeContext: Gale Avatar is speaker, his bomb is a surprise to us

414.speaker: Astarion
414.text: Tell me I misheard, Gale. Because how would that make sense? How would that even be possible?

421.speaker: Player
421.text: Explain the Netherese orb and the terrible power within you.

16.speaker: Astarion
16.text: So that's why your blood tasted so foul - this magic you're harbouring.

29.speaker: Astarion
29.text: Well, what's next? Are you actually going through with this?

496.speaker: Astarion
496.text: Must you? Does Gale's will not come into it?

465.speaker: Player
465.text: Not if I can avoid it.

501.speaker: Astarion
501.text: Then find a way to avoid it.

173.speaker: Astarion
173.text: Oh no, my friend. I have my own plans.

241.speaker: Astarion
241.text: We're going to find to the Heart of the Absolute to help ourselves, not be sacrificed on the altar for some god.

1.speaker: Astarion
1.text: I hope we can agree on that. Until then, I'll give you some space.

267.speaker: Astarion
267.text: We all have our secrets, indeed.

452.speaker: Player
452.text: If it's Mystra's will, anything is possible.

174.speaker: Astarion
174.text: Gods, I can't even take solace in the lie.

314.speaker: Astarion
314.text: It is not the time to chat - move!
314.context: NodeContext: Racing through a collapsing dimension, trying to reach the dream figure 'Daisy'

320.speaker: Astarion
320.text: Honestly? I don't love walking into a den of killer gith warriors.

82.speaker: Astarion
82.text: Especially not with the you-know-whats still wriggling in our heads.

489.speaker: Astarion
489.text: The gith probably think decapitation is a perfectly reasonable 'cure'.

322.speaker: Astarion
322.text: Wyll gave up his father to have freedom? An understandable decision. Sacrifices must be made, after all.

77.speaker: Astarion
77.text: Especially if the old Duke's fall means his rise.

328.speaker: Astarion
328.text: Wyll's devil is a sly little wretch, I'll give her that.

333.speaker: Astarion
333.text: Even a wet rag like Zevlor deserved a better death than that.

335.speaker: Astarion
335.text: I know the look is meant to be very 'murder' heavy, but it's a bit much. Even for me.

336.speaker: Astarion
336.text: So, Mystra's requested a chat with Gale? Unusually polite for a god.

337.speaker: Astarion
337.text: You almost pity Orin, taking Minthara like that. Give her half a chance and she'll gut the shapeshifter like a fish.

339.speaker: Astarion
339.text: What in the nine Hells is going on? I thought we had him!
339.context: NodeContext: Defeated the Big Boss Ketheric, but he has now retreated to the Colony, and the party saw a giant tentacle burst through the roof of the Tower. High intensity situation.

259.speaker: Astarion
259.text: Nothing to do but follow him and finish the job.
259.context: NodeContext: Defeated the Big Boss Ketheric, but he has now retreated to the Colony, and the party saw a giant tentacle burst through the roof of the Tower. High intensity situation.

350.speaker: Astarion
350.text: I've killed my fair share of people, but wiping out an entire building with a cannon powered by the sun?

353.speaker: Astarion
353.text: Well. That will take some time to process.
353.context: NodeContext: Big "Wow, that escalated quickly" vibes.

351.speaker: Astarion
351.text: So, Gale's agreed to be a good boy and hand the Crown over to Mystra?

356.speaker: Astarion
356.text: Defying Mystra, declaring that he'll rule the Karsite Weave - I didn't know Gale had it in him.

357.speaker: Astarion
357.text: I'm almost tempted to tell Shadowheart what she did. To see if I can jog her memory.

481.speaker: Astarion
481.text: I doubt Shar would take kindly to anyone meddling in her little project, though.

369.speaker: Astarion
369.text: So, Gale's hedging his bets with Mystra. I can't say I blame him.

392.speaker: Astarion
392.text: Who'd want to hold a power like the Crown of Karsus in their hands, just to hand it to someone else?

187.speaker: Astarion
187.text: I know what my decision would be. But we're all different, of course.

370.speaker: Astarion
370.text: I can't believe Orpheus wants one of us to transform.

446.speaker: Astarion
446.text: I did not go to the Hells and back because I like his company - if anyone has to make the sacrifice it should be him.

375.speaker: Astarion
375.text: All I wanted was to get a worm out of my head - I didn't sign up for dimensional travel and murderous gith.

456.speaker: Astarion
456.text: Present company excluded, of course. You can be murderous as you like.

376.speaker: Astarion
376.text: I really thought you and Shadowheart might fight to the death over that artefact.

379.speaker: Astarion
379.text: You almost pity Orin, taking Lae'zel like that. Give her half a chance and she'll rip out the shapeshifter's spine.

384.speaker: Astarion
384.text: Just like that hulking bear to stomp off in a huff.

316.speaker: Astarion
316.text: I swear, druids care more about the plants of this land than the people.

385.speaker: Astarion
385.text: I hope you don't make a habit of betraying your travelling companions.

409.speaker: Astarion
409.text: Not that I wouldn't understand - respect it even - but it does leave one a little nervous.

387.speaker: Astarion
387.text: Of all the places you've dragged me, this might just be the most foul.

85.speaker: Astarion
85.text: And that's saying something, given some of the things you've exposed me to.

389.speaker: Astarion
389.text: So, we have the hammer. Now all we have to do is...

517.speaker: Astarion
517.text: Actually I'm not really clear on what we have to do, but I assume we're smashing something.

390.speaker: Astarion
390.text: Shadowheart's parents are at peace. And so's she, it seems.

391.speaker: Astarion
391.text: No matter what Jaheira says, immortality is a difficult drug to kick.

243.speaker: Astarion
243.text: She'll hold on to that scroll for as long as she can bear to. And perhaps a century or two longer than that.

398.speaker: Astarion
398.text: We should tell Aylin that Lorroakan is hunting her. She has a right to know.

380.speaker: Astarion
380.text: Also, she'll want to cave his skull in and, honestly, I would not mind seeing that.

401.speaker: Astarion
401.context: NodeContext: Standing on the streets of Baldur's Gate, looking at them in the sun with new wonder.

429.speaker: Astarion
429.text: This is the first time in two hundred years I've seen these streets in the sunlight.
429.context: NodeContext: Standing on the streets of Baldur's Gate, looking at them in the sun with new wonder.

170.speaker: Astarion
170.text: You can forget just how much colour there is in the world.
170.context: NodeContext: Standing on the streets of Baldur's Gate, looking at them in the sun with new wonder.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: Come on, focus up. We have work to do.

12.speaker: Astarion
12.text: Hmm? Yes, of course we do. I was just...
12.context: NodeContext: Trying to gather himself, ends with one last look at the street before him (over the shoulder of the player in front of him)

345.speaker: Player
345.text: Paint a picture, it'll last longer.

478.speaker: Astarion
478.text: Hmm? Oh - yes, your trademark wit.

332.speaker: Astarion
332.text: Now, what do you want, exactly?

116.speaker: Player
116.text: Looks a little gaudy if you ask me. Give me grey any day.

505.speaker: Astarion
505.text: Inconceivable as it might be, I actually didn't ask you.
505.context: NodeContext: Still a little lost in the moment

417.speaker: Astarion
417.text: I want to be clear - letting Minthara tag along with us was your idea. So if you wake up with a dagger to your throat, that's on you.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: Better a dagger at my throat than fangs, Astarion.

205.speaker: Astarion
205.text: But fine, take her if you wish. Just know I'll be resting with one eye open.

13.speaker: Astarion
13.text: I hope so, otherwise we may all be killed in our beds.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: Jealous you're no longer the least trustworthy person in our camp?

80.speaker: Astarion
80.text: Excuse me - I'm sorry for looking out for our collective hides.

418.speaker: Astarion
418.text: I don't care what he's offering - I wouldn't have been so quick to sign with the devil.

250.speaker: Astarion
250.text: Then again, it's not my name on the page, so what should I care?

19.speaker: Astarion
19.text: It seems to me like there's a clear path forward. Karlach just has to walk it.

422.speaker: Astarion
422.text: So, we owe our continued survival to a rebel squid and a prisoner prince.

404.speaker: Astarion
404.text: I almost preferred it when we were worried we might transform at any moment.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: We need to get rid of these parasites, quick.

22.speaker: Astarion
22.text: Well - hold on, I didn't say that. The parasites still have their advantages.
22.context: NodeContext: suddenly backtracking as the player throws the baby out with the bathwater

448.speaker: Astarion
448.text: And who knows, they might even have some new tricks to reveal?

365.speaker: Player
365.text: Protection is protection - I'll take whatever I can get.

138.speaker: Astarion
138.text: It is better than sprouting tentacles, I'll give you that.

239.speaker: Player
239.text: You're missing the bigger picture. We could get a lot of power out of this.

35.speaker: Astarion
35.text: I suppose that is a point.

440.speaker: Astarion
440.text: And our cranial guests already came with some advantages - maybe there're more to uncover.

438.speaker: Astarion
438.text: Still, I don't like being under anyone's thumb. The sooner we can turn the tables and start pulling their strings, the better.

423.speaker: Astarion
423.text: So much for the cavalry riding to our rescue.

444.speaker: Astarion
444.text: This is what we get for putting our faith in a network of spies, I suppose.

431.speaker: Astarion
431.text: The parasite must be playing with my ears, because I was sure that beardy tramp told Gale to find the Heart of the Absolute and then blow himself up.
431.context: InternalNodeContext: Gale Avatar is NOT speaker, his bomb is a surprise to us

433.speaker: Astarion
433.text: This is what happens when you trust the gith: they strap you to a machine and try to kill you.

90.speaker: Astarion
90.text: At least there's no permanent damage done. Or not too much permanent damage? I suppose time will tell.

435.speaker: Astarion
435.text: Gods, I never though I'd be so relieved to find a light in the darkness.

530.speaker: Astarion
530.text: Or to see so many Harpers clanking about.

439.speaker: Astarion
439.text: So, Shadowheart stood up to the Dark Lady? I'm almost impressed.

447.speaker: Astarion
447.text: I was sure I saw you with one of our more magical, and more valuable, items earlier. Any idea where it is now?

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Tell him about the Netherese orb and your need to consume magic to keep it at bay.

153.speaker: Astarion
153.context: NodeContext: Just been told that Gale could explode, killing everyone

506.speaker: Astarion
506.text: I suppose we can spare the occasional trinket if it stops you from killing us all.

121.speaker: Astarion
121.text: Just try not to consume anything too expensive or powerful. You may need magic, but I need coin.

60.speaker: Astarion
60.text: Yes, but I'd rather not lose any more valuable artefacts, if it's all the same to you.

132.speaker: Astarion
132.text: I don't care what you do with them - we all have our secrets - just don't empty my pack to feed whatever it is you have going on.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: You must be mistaken - I haven't seen it.

453.speaker: Astarion
453.text: So, we kill Gortash or Halsin dies? It's not an easy call.

402.speaker: Astarion
402.text: One the one hand, killing Gortash would be fun. On the other, Halsin can be very annoying.

315.speaker: Astarion
315.text: We probably should save the druid, though. He does have his uses.

460.speaker: Astarion
460.context: NodeContext: Rolling the name around in your mouth, trying it on for size

216.speaker: Astarion
216.text: I'm sure her parents meant well, but the name's a little ominous isn't it?

484.speaker: Astarion
484.text: Unless she chose it herself. Which is even more worrying, honestly.

464.speaker: Astarion
464.text: I really thought Shadowheart and Lae'zel might fight to the death over that artefact.

467.speaker: Astarion
467.text: Credit where it's due: Shadowheart is tenacious. And tougher than I expected.

344.speaker: Astarion
344.text: Pain can break anyone, but she bore it well and got what she wanted.

415.speaker: Astarion
415.text: Even if she's damned herself to a lifetime of that same pain.

469.speaker: Astarion
469.text: I'm still thinking about Karlach. About what she said.
469.context: NodeContext: Heard karlach give a big, emotional speech about how she's going to die

311.speaker: Astarion
311.text: Gods. There really is no justice in the world.

473.speaker: Astarion
473.text: Won't be long now. They'll pay for what they did to me.
473.context: NodeContext: thinking about killing the mind flayers - low-level anger

474.speaker: Astarion
474.text: So, Gale's agreed to be a good boy and hand the Crown over to Mystra?

178.speaker: Astarion
178.text: I can't say I would have made the same call, but each to their own.

482.speaker: Astarion
482.text: So, you chose your family over your god.

179.speaker: Astarion
179.text: I hope you don't come to regret it.

486.speaker: Astarion
486.text: So, that's how the legend ends. The Blade of Frontiers, cast down to the Hells.

269.speaker: Astarion
269.text: Hardly a fitting ending. But so few are.

490.speaker: Astarion
490.text: I could tell Shadowheart was tough, but a killer?

54.speaker: Astarion
54.text: I'm surprised, she has more steel than I thought.

512.speaker: Astarion
512.text: You know, I never dreamed our noble Jaheira would be such a terrible, terrible mother.

297.speaker: Astarion
297.text: It's nice to see heroes are as awful as the rest of us.

513.speaker: Astarion
513.text: So, Lae'zel's finally seen the light and turned on her mistress.

378.speaker: Astarion
378.text: It took a little time, but she got there.

113.speaker: Astarion
113.text: Though it's not over yet. Masters rarely let their slaves go without a fight.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: Let her come. I'll be ready.

53.speaker: Astarion
53.text: I hope you will. For all our sakes.

514.speaker: Astarion
514.text: But that's a problem for the future. What are we doing now?

319.speaker: Player
319.text: And if she does chase me - will you stand with me?

46.speaker: Astarion
46.text: How could I not fight for such a noble cause?

301.speaker: Astarion
301.text: Unless you're going to lose, in which case I would have to think about it.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: This is none of your concern.

323.speaker: Astarion
323.text: Not yet, but it will become my concern very quickly if a pissed-off god-queen sends a legion of warriors after you.

507.speaker: Astarion
507.text: Not that I mind you sticking a thumb in your slaver's eye, I just like to keep track of who wants us dead.

515.speaker: Astarion
515.text: I expected Nightsong to be overjoyed after killing her 'fair-haired fool'.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: Maybe vengeance isn't all its cracked up to be.

436.speaker: Astarion
436.text: No... No, I don't think that's it.

41.speaker: Astarion
41.text: She probably just needs some time for it to sink in. I'm sure she'll be elated soon.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Worried you'll feel the same way when you kill Cazador?

100.speaker: Astarion
100.text: Hardly, it's going to be the greatest moment of my life.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: How did you feel after killing Cazador?

352.speaker: Astarion
352.text: The blood, the screaming - just thinking about it makes me smile.

70.speaker: Astarion
70.text: Not what I'd expected. There was a sense of... emptiness.

329.speaker: Astarion
329.text: Maybe it's just hard to see someone else suffer the same thing. It feels unfair - like justice denied.

382.speaker: Astarion
382.text: Still, it's done. That's what matters.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: She's probably just a better person than you are.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: No laughing, no delirious smile. It was bizarre.

516.speaker: Astarion
516.text: So, Shar's chosen walks among us. How lucky we are.

133.speaker: Astarion
133.text: Still, if this means we can take a shot at Ketheric, it may well be worth it.

527.speaker: Astarion
527.text: If the shapechanger wants Gortash dead, then let's kill Gortash and get Yenna back.

204.speaker: Astarion
204.text: Not that I care, it's just that children have a habit of disappearing in this city. Let's not let any more slip away.

531.speaker: Astarion
531.text: I do admire how you got that lantern, you know.

279.speaker: Astarion
279.text: Not just your craftsmanship, although the dead pixies are - 'mwah'.
279.context: NodeContext: as if complimenting a chef

78.speaker: Astarion
78.text: But being willing to turn away from what you know. To turn away from the light and bend the darkness to your will.

71.speaker: Astarion
71.text: I see you, Gale of Waterdeep. I see you.
71.context: NodeContext: "I see you, you evil little boy"
